Author: Seko#7408
Content: Can you explain me why it's not possible to reach 51% from Bitcoin or Ethereum hashrate? And how realistic is a quantum computer?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 1. It is, it's just hard. 2) They already exist

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: VerusCoin is a KMD fork that uses a quantum-resistant hash function, VerusHash: veruscoin.io

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: It might be quantum resitant, but it requires "cryptographic" functions of modern CPU's which all contain a hardware back door.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @blackjok3r not quite, I am talking about an abstract property of the hash function, you are talking about efficiently mining

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Quantum computers can bruteforce double-sha256 and Equihash much more effectively, no such speedup exists for VerusHash, i.e. quantum computers are not more effective against it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure QC can do hashing efficiently

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: mathematical functiions yes, hashing not so much

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: not yet üòÉ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: VerusHash is basically a variable-input extension of Haraka v2, which has a bunch of stuff about attacks with QC's in this paper: https://eprint.iacr.org/2016/098.pdf

Author: Seko#7408
Content: Thx for the answers. I don‚Äôt know VerusCoin yet...

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
@dukeleto https://github.com/imylomylo/docker-komodo-smartcontracts
OR if you don't have docker, just run 

```
komodod  -daemon -regtest &
komodo-cli  -regtest getinfo
komodo-cli  -regtest generate 101
komodo-cli  -regtest getnewaddress
komodo-cli  -regtest getwalletinfo
```

Smart contracts
```
komodod  -ac_cc=1 -ac_name=ATEST -addressindex=1 -spentindex=1 -ac_supply=1000 -ac_reward=10000000000000 -pubkey=033ace50aedf8df70035b962a805431363a61cc4e69d99d90726a2d48fb195f68c -regtest &

komodo-cli -ac_name=ATEST -regtest faucetinfo
```

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: not sure if you're familiar with bitcoin regtest, but after 100 blocks you get the first block reward of 50BTC https://bitcoin.org/en/developer-examples#regtest-mode

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
```
komodo-cli -regtest getgenerate
false
```
you can't set it to true with `komodo-cli -regtest setgenerate true 101`
```
error code: -32601
error message:
Use the generate method instead of setgenerate on this network
```
And so you use `generate` and you only generate blocks.  No block reward - so you can't actually send anything cos no coins exist.
HTH

Author: dukeleto#7326

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: because I can't run a normal kmd server and regtest on the same machine (port conflict)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ALSO, if you ignore the error message that it cannot start it's HTTP server and run `komodo-cli  -regtest getinfo` it works!!! But it's not regtest. Because regtest + mainnet have the same port, which seems like a üí© idea

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: choosing port numbers, gotta think of something good

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ```Generate 101 blocks using a special RPC which is only available in regtest mode. This takes less than a second on a generic PC. Because this is a new block chain using Bitcoin‚Äôs default rules, the first blocks pay a block reward of 50 bitcoins. Unlike mainnet, in regtest mode only the first 150 blocks pay a reward of 50 bitcoins. However, a block must have 100 confirmations before that reward can be spent, so we generate 101 blocks to get access to the coinbase transaction from block #1.```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this is where things sound üê† `And so you use generate and you only generate blocks.  No block reward - so you can't actually send anything cos no coins exist.`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: by default, the first 150 blocks have a block reward in regtest (I am not sure if the regtest we inherited from ZEC is different, I will look). So if you generate more blocks, you should definitely see the block reward

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just use -ac_supply=100000000

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then you have many coins

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `bitcoin-cli -regtest generate 251` in theory would generate all the regtest coins, since it has 150 + 100 for it to be mature, plus 1 for extra luck

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i have seen the "generate 101 blocks" stuff in Zcash tests, that looks familiar and they probably kept that the same. But ZEC has that slow ramp up junk and founders reward stuff, kmd doesn't, so I don't know if our regtest modes have slight differences

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: BTC core defines a static port (18443) in their chainparams.cpp, ZEC has 18232

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: KMD kept the 18232

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `generate 101` seems kind of slow, how long does it take for you @Mylo ?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it being this slow is one of the reasons the test suite is so slow, each test file usually generates new blocks for all the tests in that file. It took close to a minute for me, it should be closer to a few seconds
